awd_titl_txt: Lightning Initiation and In-Cloud Electromagnetic Activity in Mississippi Thunderstorms
awd_abstract_narration:
Although much is already known about lightning flashes, we still do not understand how a flash initiates.  Somehow the initiation processes turn the non-conducting air into a short, thin conductor or initial lightning channel; the rest of the flash then develops from this initial channel.  Researchers do not yet fully understand exactly what physical mechanisms cause the first sparks of a lightning flash and how those sparks transform the non-conducting air into the highly conductive lightning channel.  This study will analyze several months of lightning data to gain new understanding of initiation processes.  This project combines an unusual suite of traditional and state-of-the-art research sensors to advance the understanding of lightning initiation.  This research has strong societal impact through potentially improved understanding of lighting initiation and improved lightning warning systems.  

This research seeks to analyze lightning data collected in northern Mississippi during summer 2016 to study cloud discharge events that lead to lightning initiation.  Those events include fast positive breakdown, narrow bipolar events (NBEs), initial electric field changes (IECs), and initial breakdown pulses (IBPs).  The novelty, and potentially transformative aspect of this new research, is in the new data, which includes measurements from an electric field derivative sensor and a very high frequency (VHF) sensor.  The VHF sensor is particularly suitable for studying the lightning initiating events, because although not well understood, electrical discharges in air are known to produce HF and VHF radiation.  The analysis will take into consideration the recent discovery of fast positive breakdown and will investigate how fast positive breakdown is connected to the events that follow.  A similar line of research will be conducted to study how VHF pulses affect IECs or IBPs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Lightning flashes are remarkably interesting because each flash has large current (1000's of Amps) traveling in long, thin conducting paths (length of a mile or more with diameter less than 1 inch). Lightning is also intrinsically mysterious for two reasons: first, it begins inside a cloud that is a good insulator (rather than conductive), and second, a flash can develop its miles-long conducting path and strike the ground in less than 1/10th of a second.

 This NSF project used lightning electromagnetic data collected in a prior NSF award to study lightning flash initiation (the earliest 10-thousandths of a second) with two main goals:

(1) Learning how the 'initiation event' or IE of a flash changes the non-conductive cloudy air into short (1 - 2 yards), thin conductors. The data indicate that the IE occurs in only 1 - 10 millionths of a second.

(2) Learning how the flash then extends its length during the next few thousandths of a second. These extensions increase the conductor length by jumps of 30 - 200 meters . The jumps produce large electrical pulses that are measured and located; these pulses are called Initial Breakdown Pulses or IBPs.

 Data analyses under this project indicate that the lightning initiation event is probably caused by very energetic cosmic ray particles that start numerous positive 'streamers' when they pass through a small region in the thundercloud with a very large electric field (greater than the equivalent of 3 million Volts/meter at sea level). Together, this collection of positive streamers is the initiation event since the streamers ionize the air, thereby changing the non-conducting air into many tiny regions with relatively good conductivity.

 The data analyses in this project have led to the finding that most flashes begin with weak IEs having power less than 1 watt. Previous research suggested that some flashes are initiated with more powerful events called Initiator Narrow Bipolar Events or INBEs. The data analyzed in this project show that INBEs initiate only about 5% of cloud-to-ground flashes; those INBEs had powers of 5 - 1300 watts. A small percentage of intracloud flashes were initiated by INBEs with powers of 200 - 88,000 watts.

 Past laboratory measurements have shown positive streamers quickly transition into thin conductors called 'UPFs' (for 'unusual plasma formations'). According to postulation under this project, after the initiation event within a thundercloud, each positive streamer transitions into a short UPF. UPFs that are close enough to each other in the cloud connect to make longer UPFs; many UPFs can connect to make three-dimensional (3-D) networks of conducting UPFs. When two UPFs connect, there will be a small electrical pulse emitted that is detected; the power and location of each pulse can thus be estimated. Hence, in this dataset the construction of a 3-D UPF network is indicated by detecting a localized group of small electrical pulses that occur as the various UPFs connects to another. The 3-D UPF networks should grow larger and larger and reach linear dimensions of 50 - 100 meters. Work under this project has led to a postulation that the first IBP detected is caused when two large UPF networks that are close to each other connect. The second IBP occurs when another large UPF network connects to the two networks that combined to made the first IBP. The data analyzed show that a large IBP occurs when its location is between two previously developed groups.

 The large amplitude IBPs found in these data are an indication of large currents flowing through the connected UPF networks. Prior research has shown that 3 - 12 IBPs occur in each lightning flash before the channel extends via a self-propagating 'stepped leader,' and stepped leaders have been known for decades as the main way a lightning channel extends either to ground or to another part of the cloud. Extension as a stepped leader requires a very hot conductor. Thus the sequence of IBPs that occurs just after the Initiating Event seems to be required in order to make the conducting path hotter and hotter until the stepped leader can begin.

 Broader outcomes of this project include 6 peer-reviewed journal articles plus one manuscript revision still under review. These publications have thus far been cited 75 times in other literature. Results from the project have been presented and discussed at numerous scientific conferences. One PhD dissertation was completed under the project and a second PhD dissertation analyzing the dataset is nearing completion. One post-doctoral researcher was mentored as part of the project.
